sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Hello, you're watching Euronews tonight. Here are our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Slovakia is the latest European country to impose new restrictions on unvaccinated people as COVID-19 cases continue rising.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Belarus clears migrant camps along its border with Poland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: People are moved to a warehouse that's now becoming overcrowded as the first repatriation flights to Iraq land in Erbil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: overcrowded as the first repatriation flights to Iraq land in Erbil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Doubts raised over the veracity of an email said to be sent from the missing Chinese tennis player Peng Xiaoyi.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And an HIV patient has reportedly become the second person in the world to be naturally cured without treatment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Good evening and welcome to the program. I'm Takumbo Salako. Slovakia is imposing

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: new restrictions on the unvaccinated in the latest effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Under the new rules, only people who've been fully vaccinated or who've recovered in the last six months will be allowed into restaurants, shopping malls, gyms, pools and hotels. Mass public gatherings such as sports events will also require vaccination proof.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The country has one of the EU's lowest vaccination rates with 45 percent of people fully immunized.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: On Wednesday, Bratislava registered more than 8,000 new cases, a new daily record.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: than 8,000 new cases, a new daily record. Austria has also registered a new record of infections with more than 15,000 people testing positive for Covid-19 in the last 24 hours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The regions of Upper Austria and Salzburg will impose full restrictive measures for all people from Monday for several weeks. Vienna is now under pressure to start a full national lockdown to avoid a collapse of its health system. People in Germany, meanwhile, will have to show full proof of vaccination or a valid negative COVID-19 test to access workplaces and public transport.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Work-from-home rules will also be reinstated as lawmakers in the lower house pass new legislation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Thuringia, Saxony and Bavaria are the most affected states.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Health officials have warned that the real case numbers may be much higher due to a lag in reporting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The head of the country's disease control agency said the country could face a really terrible Christmas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Let's get more details on those measures in Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now we can speak to Kate Brady, our reporter in Berlin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Kate, good to see you there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Give us some more details of these new rules passed by the Bundestag today and how do they differ from the current ones?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, what we definitely won't see this time around is if it is indeed passed by the upper house of parliament tomorrow is that there won't be any blanket measures this time around is if it is indeed passed by the upper house of parliament tomorrow is that there won't be any blanket measures this time around so no nationwide school closures closures of businesses and the idea behind that really is to just try and avoid that upheaval and instead the incoming or likely incoming government which proposed these new plans these new coronavirus measures they want to rely on what they're calling the 3G and 2G rules, which are a mix really of proving either whether you're vaccinated or recently recovered, that's the 2G rule, or the 3G rule is the same as the 2G, but you can also show that you've recently tested negative. So there are several things, basic pandemic rules, if you will, that people will recognise here, like mandatory mask wearing, social distancing and basic hygiene rules. But of course, as you mentioned, one of the big things is this 3G rule, having to prove that you're vaccinated, recovered or negative, have a negative test to go into the workplace and also to go on public transport. There's already in the last couple of days, though, been a huge amount of criticism, especially from rail services and local transport operators, demanding to know how this is going to be implemented, saying that many of their workers are saying that they don't want to have to ask people whether they can prove that they're vaccinated, recovered or have a negative test because of some of the lashback really, backlash against some of these new rules. At the same time, Kate, Angela Merkel's been meeting with regional leaders. She's under pressure to sort of oversee joint coordinated action. So what additional steps are they looking at or considering?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: action. So what additional steps are they looking at or considering?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, the main point of that meeting is to create some sense of unity. And you might be able to remember, especially last winter and earlier this spring as well, when Germany was facing a particularly tough second and third wave, there was no real sense of unity. We had this patchwork of measures around the country, and that's what we've started to see just in the last few weeks as the fourth wave has really hit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: You mentioned Saxony and Bavaria in particular have been most badly hit by this fourth wave so far. Those two were two of the first states to really tighten the measures, now demanding people to show that they're either vaccinated or recently recovered just to go into a restaurant or a gym cinemas to the hairdressers for example as well so it is likely that we could see maybe a so-called 2g rule in across all of germany's 16 states but of course another huge issue as well that they're debating is how to get more people vaccinated and this is the huge issue that's been highlighted as being behind the the reason why germany has been so badly hit by the fourth wave you know only 68 of the entire population is currently fully vaccinated so not only is there the effort right now to get more people vaccinated the first time around but also to enable people who are now eligible for a booster shot to go and get their third or in some cases second shot kate brady there on those new measures being considered and coming into force in germany thank you joining me now is professor laurence

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: young he's a virologist and professor of molecular oncology at the University of Birmingham in the UK. Thanks for taking time to speak to us here on the program. Well is it, as our reporter was just suggesting there, this problem across Europe is down to not enough people getting vaccinated or is it just because we're all becoming a bit too relaxed? I think it's a combination isn't it? We've all become a bit complacent about this virus but what we're seeing at the moment is a product of both insufficient vaccine aptitude and premature easing of restriction measures. We took our eye off the ball far too early. And sadly, we're living with the consequences. Well, a growing list of countries, as we've been reporting this week, are now approving booster jabs, many for sort of those over 60s, only Germany Germany which was suggested for everyone over 18. is that the way to go well if we look at other countries and the country that we always look at as an example is Israel where they saw very high numbers of cases over the summer and then decided to roll out booster vaccines into the entire population all the over 12s and they've seen a significant drop in not only the number of cases, but just as if not more importantly, the number of people getting into hospital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And we know that for people who are vulnerable and elderly and were vaccinated at the beginning of the vaccine rollout, their immunity starts to decay.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It starts to wane.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Booster shots have a profound impact on that and are an excellent way of protecting everybody, but it's just not vaccines alone. You have to have other measures.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: OK. What does that mean then we can look forward to, perhaps if look forward, that's the right term, to a future where we're having regular booster jabs, you know, much like some of us have to do for the flu virus?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yeah, I think if we can just get over this winter period, we always knew winter was going to be challenging.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The virus hasn't got away anywhere. It spreads more easily over the winter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It's compounded by other respiratory infections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: If we can get over this hump, then I suspect that what we're going to end up with is having to have at least annual jabs for the next few years to keep the virus under control.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And it may be in time that we won't need jabs at all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But I think for the foreseeable future, we're going to have to have top up booster jabs at all. But I think for the foreseeable future, we're going to have to have top-up booster jabs. Now, so many people are dealing with the psychological effects of the last lockdown, with so many countries imposing these new measures on the unvaccinated. What additional measures can be put in place for them? How do we get over the line in terms of convincing them to perhaps take the jab? Well, clearly, we really do have to do something about these folk who are hesitant around the vaccine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We have so much data now, and I think the governments need to do their best of being more persuasive, with better messaging about the value and safety of vaccination.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But also alongside that, it's quite clear that we have to do something to compel people more to wear face masks in crowded spaces and to socially distance where possible and also where possible work from home for a while until we get over this very difficult situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Important now that we take as much pressure off of our health systems across Europe as possible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And the only way to do that is to get more people jabbed and more people behaving cautiously.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Would you be in favour then of a return to those blanket bans? Germany's got to put it on the back burner for now. Total closures of schools, for example, and keeping more people at home? I think that's just a bit radical. We know that vaccination has really significantly weakened the link between infections and hospitalisations. So we're not in the same situation we were a year ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But we are worried.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I mean, the more the virus spreads, the more likely it is to throw up another variant that could be more resistant to the vaccine, for instance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So it's really important that we dampen down infection with vaccination and that we prevent the spread of the virus with wearing face masks and being cautious.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Otherwise, we will end up in a situation where more drastic measures will be required. Professor Lawrence Young, a virologist at the University of Birmingham in the UK, thanks for joining us on the programme. Thank you very

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: much indeed. Now, Polish officials say that all migrants in the main camp on the Belarusian side of the border have been cleared and the people brought to another location. On Wednesday, Belarusian forces started moving people from the makeshift camps following an increasing number of clashes with Polish border forces earlier this week. Some of the migrants have been provided shelter by Minsk in a warehouse facility close to the border area, but voices from inside the building say it's currently being overwhelmed as you can see this is the camp that Belarus has built for us it is a warehouse and we are all inside now at first the situation was good I mean on the first day we were receiving three meals a day but as more people came in from the forest it has got more and more crowded. As a result, we got no dinner yesterday and no lunch today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: As you can see, it is getting very crowded here and it is not easy to find a place to sit or to sleep.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It's hard to charge our phones.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So in general, the situation is not good here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But it is much better than staying in the forest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The situation there was very bad and very complicated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The Iraqi government has stepped into the ongoing crisis and repatriated hundreds of its citizens stranded in Belarus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: On Thursday, 430 people were registered to board a chartered plane from Minsk to Baghdad with a stopover in the Iraqi Kurdistan capital, Erbil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: A spokesperson for the Iraqi government says no other flights have been organized.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Valerie Goriat has been watching events unfold on the Polish side of the border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: She told us that officials remain suspicious of the motive behind Belarus' removal of the migrants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I'm standing now in front of the last checkpoint before the Kuznitsa border crossing, and it's an area where there are mixed feelings about what's going on at the moment at the Belarus border. On the one hand, the fact that hundreds of people were taken out of the cold is seen as a relative sign of goodwill by Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko, who in his phone conversation with Angela Merkel talked about humanitarian aid for the migrants. It's also seen as a communication stunt to try and redeem his image upon the international community, especially the European Union, which has just decided to hype up sanctions. The other thing is that there is concern as regards the people who are being taken away from from the border on buses. The spokesperson of the border guards here said that some of these people are seen carrying wooden logs and that can be used to make campfires. So there's a lot of speculation that they could be taken to other parts of the border only to create more crisis situations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And this is putting a lot of pressure on the security forces here. They're also getting more and more nervous and journalists have made several accounts in the past few days that their work had been increasingly impeded and the latest example is that of three photographers who said they had been beaten up by men in military gear who didn't identify themselves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And there is indeed a lot of tension.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We see military vehicles and police vehicles moving back and forth in and out of the no-go zone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And this is causing some anxiety among the local population who are not used to this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But they're also supportive and grateful to their security forces, which they say are protecting their borders and protecting them from what they still believe can be a potential disaster.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Valery Gorya from eastern Poland for Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews tonight. Time for us to take a break, but we'll be back in a few moments.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the program. It's good to have you here with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Two men convicted of assassinating the American civil rights leader Malcolm X in 1965 will be

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: exonerated for the crime. Malcolm X was shot in New York while giving a speech at the Audubon Ballroom. Mohammed Aziz and the late Khalil Islam were jailed for the killing, but both maintained their innocence. Both men's names will now be cleared after an investigation showed authorities withheld evidence in their trial.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: after an investigation showed authorities withheld evidence in their trial.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In Canada, the province of British Columbia has declared a state of emergency in the wake of landslides and heavy flooding.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The country's west coast has been hit with torrential rain over the last few days, submerging roads and hundreds of homes in floodwater.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: One person has been killed and several more have been reported missing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: There's been further concern raised over the welfare of missing Chinese tennis player Peng Xiaoyi. It follows Chinese state media publishing an email that the player is said to have written. In the letter, she says she's safe and not missing, but simply resting at home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The player has not been seen in public for weeks after alleging that she was sexually assaulted by a high-ranking Chinese government official.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In Argentina, a patient has become the second ever person to naturally recover from HIV.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Nicknamed Esperanza Patient, the woman became a scientific curiosity after the virus appears to have vanished from her body, making her only the second person believed to have cured herself of HIV without any drugs or any other treatment. Dr Matthias Lichtefeld is from the Rangon Institute at Harvard University and co-lead author of the report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Thanks for joining us here on the programme. Well, it's been described by your fellow author as the miracle of the human immune system.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Just how reliable are the tests?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Yeah, so that's really an important point.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: In this particular patient, we were able to have massive amounts of cells that we could look at.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We actually analysed 1.2 billion cells from this patient to look for traces of HIV, and we failed to detect any HIV that is intact in this patient.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We also had an opportunity to look into the placenta.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: She gave birth last year, and that placenta tissue was available for research, and we looked into 500 million cells from the placenta, and we also failed to identify intact HIV.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So we have used massive amounts of cells to look for HIV and we have failed to detect any intact HIV in this patient.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: That sounds incredible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But do you understand why or even how this is happening?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Yeah, it's important to understand that HIV really is a disease that usually doesn't get cured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Once you have it, you have it for the rest of your life.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The treatment that is currently available is only suppressing HIV.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's not getting rid of it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And this patient is really very different in that sense.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It really looks like HIV has been completely eliminated from her system.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And before, we believed these types of patients don't exist at all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So we now are in a position that we can identify these patients and learn from patients and understand how such a remarkable disease outcome is possible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And what are the chances now, then, would you say, like, reproducing this in, you know, other people suffering from HIV?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Yeah, it's hard to say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's important to understand that two persons in the world have been cured of HIV by getting a highly toxic bone marrow transplant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That was in the setting of these patients having cancer at the same time, so they received these bone marrow transplants for cancer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But simultaneously, that also cured HIV.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That's obviously something that cannot be done large scale.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's a very toxic procedure.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But I believe what we don't know currently is how many patients are out there who are cured, who are spontaneously cured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That's actually not known at this point. And once we understand that better, we can make better, like to develop better treatments for inducing that in a larger proportion of patients.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: to develop better treatments for inducing that in a larger proportion of patients.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Is that because there's still a stigma around HIV?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I mean, it is one of the biggest killers in the world, especially in places like Africa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Yeah, no, HIV remains a huge problem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: There is this excellent treatment that is available now in suppressing HIV, but as I said before, it doesn't get rid of HIV by itself so really people have to take treatment for the rest of their life specifically people who get infected at young ages so the patient that we are describing she got infected at age 30. so if there's no cure these patients have to take treatment for 50 60 continuous years that is a huge challenge in many situations, and that's why it's so important to find a cure for HIV.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, considering how long HIV has been around with us now, are you disappointed, or do you think we need a similar global approach through eradicating the virus as much as the approach we've taken towards dealing with COVID-19?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: There is a lot of investment going on already to find a cure for HIV.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's actually remarkable how much the US government, for example, is investing in finding a cure for HIV.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Also the Gates Foundation and multiple additional non-government organisations are invested into it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So I believe there is a lot of activity and we see undeniable progress in this field.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And I'm optimistic that over the next couple of years, there is additional progress that we're going to see.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Dr. Matthias Ligtefeld from the Rangon Institute at Harvard University.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Thanks for joining us to explain your research here on the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, still to come on Euronews tonight, the best works of Peter Carl Fabergé are taking pride of place at a new exhibition in London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We'll be taking a look after this break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, the work of Peter Carl Fabergé, the legendary maker of those bejewelled eggs for Russian royalty,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: is going on display in London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: From romance to revolution, will it allow the public to see the largest collection of his work in a generation up close?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Mario Bowden has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: As shoppers across the continent stock up on Christmas presents, at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, it's all about Easter eggs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This glittering exhibition celebrates the work of Carl Fabergé, the mastermind behind the famed decorative eggs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They are a plot device, a byword for luxury, craftsmanship and beauty and when you look at them closely, and I implore everybody to come to look at them, when you look at them, they are mind-blowing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They are mind-blowing creations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And they are there to entice and to, again, create that sense of wonder.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Once a major hit with the Romanov imperial family, these priceless ornaments are the pride and joy of Fabergé's extravagant Russian jewellery house.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: ...shiny and beautiful. Well, this obsidian rhinoceros is a lot more subtle, so you can really see the musculature and the details. It allows you to admire the craftsmanship without being blinded by the beauty of the object.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Speck tailors can behold the very best of Russian craftsmanship at the Royal Museum until May 2022. a double front flip off a cliff with a two-wheeled landing. Thanks for joining us on Euronews tonight. Thank you.
